products.name: The Great Gatsby
products.overview: Set in the Roaring Twenties, this classic novel explores themes of love, wealth, and the American Dream through the eyes of Jay Gatsby and narrator Nick Carraway.

products.name: In Search of Lost Time
products.overview: Swann's Way, the first part of A la recherche de temps perdu, Marcel Proust's seven-part cycle, was published in 1913. In it, Proust introduces the themes that run through the entire work.
products.long_description: Unless you are a huge fan of the book’s author.

products.name: Ulysses
products.overview: Ulysses chronicles the passage of Leopold Bloom through Dublin during an ordinary day, June 16, 1904. The title parallels and alludes to Odysseus (Latinised into Ulysses).
products.long_description: Unless you are a huge fan of the book’s author.

products.name: Don Quixote
products.overview: Alonso Quixano, a retired country gentleman in his fifties, lives in an unnamed section of La Mancha with his niece and a housekeeper. He has become obsessed with books of chivalry.
products.long_description: Unless you are a huge fan of the book’s author.

products.name: One Hundred Years of Solitude
products.overview: One of the 20th century's enduring works, One Hundred Years of Solitude is a widely beloved and acclaimed novel known throughout the world.
products.long_description: Unless you are a huge fan of the book’s author.

products.name: War and Peace
products.overview: First published in 1851, Melville's masterpiece is, in Elizabeth Hardwick's words, 'the greatest novel in American literature'.

products.name: Hamlet
products.overview: The Tragedy of Hamlet, Prince of Denmark, or more simply Hamlet, is a tragedy by William Shakespeare, believed to have been written between 1599 and 1601.
products.long_description: Unless you are a huge fan of the book’s author.

products.name: The Odyssey
products.overview: The Odyssey is one of two major ancient Greek epic poems attributed to Homer. It is, in part, a sequel to the Iliad, the other work traditionally ascribed to Homer.
products.long_description: Unless you are a huge fan of the book’s author.
